div1.p: Kean does not think Carter or Ames should be in the yellow fever painting. He suggests individuals on the Yellow Fever Roll of Honor.

My dear Dr. Hench
div1.p:
Your air mail budget came at noon today
and is replete with interest as your letters always
are. They take me away from the terrible history
which is being recorded day by day with such
startling swiftness to the pleasant memories and
records of 40 years ago. I read Dick Bullard's
sketch with interest and tho it differs from my
recollections in some details I think it is quite
accurate. I have made a marginal note or
two on it. I think the selections for the persons in
the picture have been very fair. I cannot see
why Dr. Henry R. Carter should be in it. Fine and
learned man as he was, he was not in Cuba
during the period of the Boards' mosquito experiments
(I know this from his daughter) and had no connec-
tion with its work. The only connection was the
indirect one that Reed read a magazine article
send copy to Kellogg & Truby
AC
K
2
of his and knew how to interpret the observations
which he reported having made that a case of
yellow fever brought into a community does not
product secondary cases during an interval of
(2 to 3 weeks)15 or 20 days where as non-immunes visiting an
infected house come down in 3 to 6 days(1 to 7) after
exposure. These observations were made in Miss in
1898 and it is my impression that Carter did not
know the explanation of this curious fact until
Reeds' Boards work furnished the clue, of this how
ever I am not sure as I never read Carters'
article in the A. O. Med. Jour for May 1900 in which
the observations were published. See page 70 Senate Doc. no. 822 Yellow Fever
As to Dr. Roger Post Ames's contributions, he look-
ed after the sick and made diagnosis of the
yellow fever cases, but certainly made no scientific
contribution to the work.

For giving names to the other figures in the picture
I think it would be well to take men who are
on record in the Y.F. Roll of Honor as having under-
gone more than one experiment as:

Levi E. Folk who took the Infected bedding test
& then contracted yellow fever from infected mosquitos
James E. Hanberry. Who took both & whose life
hung in the balance from his case
Jernegan took three tests. 1. Infected bedding
2. Infected mosquitos (which did not infect him and
3
then 3. a blood injection from an experimental case
which caused all attack.

What do you mean by Cuban volunteers? There
were no Cuban volunteers as the Cubans were
always supposed to be immune. I suppose
you refer to the Spanish immigrants. But dont you
think it confusing to call them Cubans. Reed in
his articles is always careful to speak of Antonio
Benigno & the others as Spanish immigrants.

I am so glad that you have sent a carbon copy
of this letter to Gen. Truby. I had a letter from him
two days ago in which he said he had not heard
from you in a long time and feared you had not
liked the freedom with which he expressed himself in
his comments on the Hemmeter photostats. In my
letter to him yesterday I assured him that it was not
so, that your attitude of mind was entirely imperson-
al and scientific and you only wanted the truth
and were not taking sides. As you have already
written it may be as well not to make any refer-
ence to this fear of his.

I am pleased to be informed of Dr. Albertini's
identification of the Mariel Group. Altho. I had
met both Dr Dominguez Roldan & Dr Hugo Roberts I do
not recall their faces at all. My memory is poor for
both faces & names. By the way is not Dr Dominguez
Roldan's first name Francisco? That is his signature to the
AC
K
4
book and letter that I had from him last spring
Or can it be that he has a brother named Alfredo.
I did not recall that Dr Albertini had such a long
neck! I am returning to you the photo, and
Bullard's sketch. You do not mark the microfilms
of data in the Nat. Archives as to be returned so
I am keeping them. If you want them back a
postal request will bring them.

The name of the doctor who signed various
reports on pages 2 & 3 is not Hon but Horr. Capt.
Edward F. Horr. He was I think a Vol. Med. Officer
who was on duty at Columbia Barracks for a short
time. I will try to get this off by air mail tonight
